Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2014 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Miles H. Wheeler is "Several Problems in the Mathematical Theory of Water Waves." The host institution for the fellowship is New York University, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Nader Masmoudi.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project concerned the mathematical theory of water waves, i.e. waves on the surface of the ocean or in a canal. We considered an idealized version of the problem (an incompressible fluid without internal friction, and usually two-dimensional motion), but importantly placed no restrictions on the size or amplitude of the waves. The focus was on single-humped or "solitary" waves. These are less well-understood than periodic groups of waves, and introduce several technical difficulties.

One goal of the project was to relate the shape and speed of a wave to the motion of fluid particles far away where the surface is nearly flat. We proved upper and lower limits on the speed of the wave, as well as an upper bound of 45 degrees on its slope in many cases. For waves in an idealized ocean with infinite depth, we also related the motion far away from the wave to the total kinetic energy and angular momentum.

Another goal was to show the (mathematical) existence of waves in new settings. We proved the existence of large single-humped waves in fluids with non-constant density. Such changes in density play an important role in the ocean, where they are due to temperature and salinity variations. The above-mentioned bounds on the speed of the wave turn out to be a crucial part of the argument.

Lastly, the award brought the awardee to New York University to collaborate with and be mentored by the sponsoring scientist. One of the fruits of this collaboration is a new approach to the study of so-called "vortex patches", another problem from fluid mechanics.
